channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Chants of 'revolution' on streets of ravaged Beirut as France's Macron mobbed by angry crowds
From sea to mountain, how an explosion devastated Beirut
She was posing for her wedding photos, then an explosion hit
item.description: A photographer in Beirut was filming a bride on her wedding day when an explosion suddenly ripped through the city.

item.title: Trump signals he'll do anything to win
Ohio Governor tests positive ahead of meeting Trump
CNN investigates Russia's claim of cutting-edge response to virus
item.description: CNN gains exclusive access to a new coronavirus testing facility in Moscow, which Russia is promoting as more effective than Western counterparts. CNN's Matthew Chance reports.

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince accused of assassination plot against senior exiled official
item.description: A former top Saudi intelligence official who fell out with the Saudi Crown Prince is alleging that an assassination squad traveled from Saudi Arabia to Canada to try to kill him just days after journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered by members of the same group, according to a new legal complaint filed Thursday by the alleged target, Dr. Saad Aljabri, in DC District Court.

item.title: Prolonged heat wave threatening Western Europe for the second weekend in a row
item.description: Western Europe is bracing for a sweltering heat wave as extreme temperatures are expected to grip the region for the second weekend in a row.

item.title: New York sues to dissolve the National Rifle Association
item.description: New York Attorney General Letitia James announced she will attempt to dissolve the National Rifle Association, accusing its senior leadership of violating laws governing non-profit groups, using millions from the organization's reserves for personal use and tax fraud.

item.title: Facebook and Twitter removed a Trump video -- and it revealed something about Fox News
Susan Rice is the VP Biden needs
item.description: Joe Biden has a high-class problem. He has a short list of highly qualified women, who would all serve as excellent running mates.

item.title: TV presenter Caroline Flack died by suicide after hearing she would be prosecuted, coroner rules
item.description: British TV presenter Caroline Flack took her own life after hearing she was definitely going to be prosecuted for allegedly assaulting her boyfriend and feared press intrusion, a coroner has ruled, according to PA Media news agency.

item.title: Michelle Obama says she's suffering from 'low-grade depression'
item.description: Former First Lady Michelle Obama says she's suffering from a "low-grade depression." The reasons? The pandemic, race relations in the US and the political strife surrounding it all, she says.

item.title: Chinese man who spent 27 years in prison for murdering two children has conviction overturned
item.description: A Chinese man convicted of murdering two children has had his conviction overturned after serving 27 years in prison, in what has been described as one of the longest-serving miscarriages of justice in recent Chinese history.

item.title: Cameron Diaz reveals why she quit acting
item.description: Former Hollywood star Cameron Diaz has revealed her reasons for retiring from the movie business, saying she found "peace" when she quit acting.

item.title: Pence says Chief Justice John Roberts has been a 'disappointment' to conservatives
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence said Wednesday that Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts "has been a disappointment to conservatives," after Roberts, who was appointed by a Republican president, sided with liberal justices this term in several major cases seen as losses for the Trump administration.

item.title: Pro cyclist in 'comatose condition' following horrific crash
item.description: Cyclist Fabio Jakobsen is in a "comatose condition" following a horrific crash at the end of the first stage of the Tour of Poland, according to his team.

item.title: Dr. Anthony Fauci: This is a predictor of trouble ahead
item.description: Dr. Anthony Fauci tells CNN's John Berman that he agrees with Dr. Deborah Birx's warning about rising coronavirus positivity rates in nine US cities and the central valley of California.

item.title: In the latest sign of Covid-19-related racism, Muslims are wrongly blamed for England's coronavirus outbreaks
item.description: Coronavirus conspiracy theorists have spread baseless rumors online -- frequently targeting minorities -- since the beginning of the pandemic. In England the latest wave of vitriol criticizes Muslims, blaming them for spreading Covid-19.

item.title: Alyssa Milano thought she was dying and tested positive for Covid-19 antibodies
item.description: Alyssa Milano says she has tested positive for coronavirus antibodies after having tested negative for Covid-19.

item.title: Los Angeles can cut off power and water at properties hosting large parties
item.description: Authorities in Los Angeles can soon request to shut off water and power from homes and businesses that host egregiously large gatherings.

item.title: Some teachers wrote their own obituaries as part of their back to school prep
item.description: Sarah Backstrom knew this school year was going to be different, even without the Covid-19 pandemic. The veteran teacher moved to Des Moines, Iowa, with her young daughters to teach in a new school district -- but this is the first time she's been scared about returning to the classroom.

item.title: Late-night host mocks Trump's use of charts during Axios interview
item.description: Late-night hosts Seth Meyers and Jimmy Fallon took shots at President Donald Trump's defense of his coronavirus response during an interview with Axios on HBO.

item.title: When a nearly 12-foot alligator came toward his 4-year-old, this dad sprung into action
item.description: Andrew Grande didn't hesitate before jumping into action when he saw a massive alligator making its way to his 4-year-old daughter.

item.title: Scientists have unraveled the riddle of this real-life sea monster
item.description: For more than a hundred years, the fossil of the Tanystropheus has puzzled scientists.

item.title: Popular YouTubers charged for bank robbery pranks
item.description: YouTube celebrities the Stokes Twins could face up to four years in state prison for their role in two fake bank robberies.

item.title: Two Black women accuse Secret Service of wrongful detention; Secret Service disputes their account
item.description: Two women say US Secret Service officers rammed into their vehicle near the White House last Thursday evening, and surrounded and pointed guns at them before handcuffing and detaining them, leaving their babies unattended and crying.

item.title: Zoe Saldana apologizes for playing Nina Simone in panned 2016 biopic
item.description: Actress Zoe Saldana has apologized for playing Nina Simone in a 2016 biopic, four years after she was heavily criticized for darkening her skin and wearing a prosthetic nose for the role.

item.title: This is the price Lebanon may pay for the blast
item.description: The port of Beirut, where the massive explosion occurred, is the main hub for imports-dependent Lebanon. The effect of the blast will be another heavy blow to the country's already crippling economy. CNN's Nina Dos Santos reports.

item.title: US special envoy for Iran stepping down
item.description: The State Department's special envoy for Iran is stepping down from his post, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced Thursday.

item.title: Monsoon drenches the Korean Peninsula with flooding rains
item.description: South Korea is in the midst of one of its wettest monsoon seasons in recent memory.

item.title: Seabird poop is worth millions, say scientists trying to save the birds
item.description: Trying to raise awareness about the importance of seabird conservation, scientists set out to quantify their contributions by valuing their feces. As it turns out, failing to protect seabirds could cost nearly half a billion dollars annually.

item.title: Prehistoric 'hell ants' hunted their prey with unusual headgear
item.description: Sometime during the Cretaceous period, 99 million years ago, a prehistoric hell ant trapped a tasty treat -- a relative of the cockroach -- in its scythe-like jaw and protruding horn.

item.title: Woman attacks another after she is asked to put on mask
item.description: A woman has been charged with aggravated assault for allegedly attacking another woman after she asked her to properly wear a face mask at a New Jersey Staples store, police said.

item.title: 'Wonder Woman 1984' debuts new teaser
item.description: We're getting another glimpse at the upcoming "Wonder Woman 1984."

item.title: This may be the safest, and most fun, way to fly in 2020
item.description: Avgeek desktop gamers and wannabe airline captains can finally get the high-altitude fix they've been craving.

item.title: LeBron James laughs off Trump's criticism of NBA players taking a knee
item.description: NBA star LeBron James says the league won't miss Donald Trump's viewership after the US President criticized players for kneeling during the national anthem.

item.title: Bryson DeChambeau consuming '6,000 calories a day' to add 40 pounds of muscle -- trainer
item.description: When Bryson DeChambeau returned to the course in June, following golf's shutdown because of Covid-19, he was packing an additional 40 pounds of muscle and hitting prodigious drives off the tee. So, naturally, people sat up and took notice.

item.title: How a yellow jersey is dividing Brazil
item.description: Brazil's bright yellow jersey is a symbol that unites the country through a love of football and national pride, but over the past two years the shirt's adoption by right wing supporters of Jair Bolsonaro, who wear it at protests and rallies to show their political allegiance to the Brazilian president, is causing controversy.

item.title: Time slipping between your fingers? Try this simple hack to make the clock work for you
item.description: During this extended period of evolving schedules and dissolving plans, in which many of us no longer "go" to work or school or much of anywhere, time feels increasingly fluid.

item.title: Why this startup is making honeybees smarter
item.description: Honeybees are essential for pollinating many crops but their populations are declining. Beeflow says its special nutrient-packed "superfood" formula can improve their performance and immune system.

item.title: American billionaire agrees deal to buy Italian football giant AS Roma
item.description: US billionaire Dan Friedkin has agreed a deal to purchase AS Roma, the Italian soccer giant confirmed on Thursday.

item.title: The student creating African emojis to change the story of Africa from poverty to beauty
item.description: When Ivorian artist O'Plerou Denis Grebet was looking for free stock images of Africa for a project, he only came across negative images of disease and poverty.

item.title: The latest US food trend is 1950s nostalgia with the return of carhops
item.description: When the coronavirus pandemic shut down his restaurants, Colton Weiss knew that to survive, he would need a creative (and safe) solution to keep serving his customers.

item.title: CNN Style looks back on six decades of Dolly Parton
item.description: For over six decades, on stage and screen, Dolly Parton's look has remained unmistakable. CNN Style looks back.

item.title: The trail of destruction left from sea to mountain of the Lebanese capital
Chants of 'revolution' in Beirut as Macron is mobbed by crowds
item.description: Shock at the devastation caused by the massive port explosion in Beirut was giving way to anger Thursday, as new information emerged that officials in the Lebanese capital had ignored repeated warnings about a stockpile of dangerous chemicals linked to the blast.

item.title: 'It was a massacre.' Hear from witnesses of explosion
item.description: A massive explosion rocked Lebanon's capital city on August 4, leaving scores of people dead and thousands wounded. Locals recount the scary moments of the blast.

item.title: The Russian backstory to the Beirut explosion
item.description: As Lebanon's investigation into the devastating blast in Beirut continues, officials have pointed to a possible cause: A massive shipment of agricultural fertilizer that authorities say was stored in the port of Beirut without safety precautions for years -- despite warnings by local officials.

item.title: Lebanon's economy was already in crisis. Then the blast hit Beirut
item.description: A cataclysmic blast in Beirut, Lebanon's capital, is poised to send an economy already deep in crisis hurtling toward a dangerous unknown.
